Wow Destin that is awesome.  My question for the president is actually about fire ecology.  As climate change changes the historic nature of how fires burn compounded on how we have changed the historic nature of fire in forest and other north american ecosystems will we be changing how we protect and create fire healthy ecosystems.  The long standing policies of suppression and restoration after the fire event is now only expensive and dangerous (take for example the fires in the pacific north west last year) but often leave large ecosystem gaps.  We have more than a few fire dependent plants on the threatened list and many bird, bug, and mammal species the depend on fire for population dynamics and control.  Is there any way we can take the several millions being spent on one fire event ( example the Canyon Creek Complex fire in Oregon last year that spent over a million a day of fire suppression) and use that economic resource for ecosystem health and restoration such as thinning and prescribed fire?  I am sure you can make this question sound better.  Just a question from an ecologist trying to make a living and trying to help make healthier ecosystems.

My question: Neal Stephenson has written a few essays ("Space stasis", in Slate; "Innovation Starvation", in World Policy Journal; and earlier, "Turn on, tune in, veg out", in NYT) arguing that one of the great problems that the US in particular, and the world in general, is facing is the loss of will to get big things done. With few exceptions (e.g., Elon Musk), we don't undertake ambitious engineering projects (the "put a man on the Moon by the end of the decade" ambition level) anymore, and both governments and private enterprises are largely averse to the kind of innovation that requires taking big risks, preferring instead diminishing returns over existing technologies. Do you agree? If so, what measures would you take to promote the emergence of more people with an Elon Musk-type mentality?

Quote from Stephenson that summarizes this concern: "I was at a conference a few years ago where I ran into an incredibly bright young man who in another age would have been laying a transatlantic cable or building the first airplane or something. And he was spending all his time writing spam filters. I'm sure it was incredibly demanding mental work and quite useful, but it struck me that, in a way, it seems as though our scope has been reduced quite a bit when the brightest people of the generation are writing silly little apps or spam filters or what have you." (bbc.com/news/technology-24116925)

Given that your channel is so dedicated to science and learning, I'd like to hear if the president (or various parties) have an opinion on or plan to deal with the anti-intellectualism epidemic. I'd like to know, not how to deal with antivaxxers and the like, but rather, how we can create a better-informed nation so the antivaxxers never come to exist in the first place.

It's very frustrating for me to hear people endorsing that kind of pseudoscientific nonsense, especially some of the candidates currently running. I know President Obama is on the way out, but I would like to know what kind of scientific legacy he's leaving for the next president. I'm glad we're revamping NASA, I'm glad we're exploring private partnerships with companies like SpaceX. The new space race to Mars is so amazing, and I'd like to believe that we'll get to Mars well within my lifetime. We have so many programs towards space and engineering, but what about biology and medicine? People are so concerned with CEOs like Martin Shkreli who want to take advantage of us, but I feel like that problem is solved by creating a new generation of medical scientists willing to create new drugs without the greed associated with people like Shkreli. People are so terrified of Monsanto, but only because people aren't willing to educate themselves about bioengineering. There are great resources like Smarter Every Day and the other youtubers, but people just aren't listening.

It's not the president's responsibility to deal with these problems, but I'd like to think that with as much as Obama has done for us with continuing our space exploration programs, he would be interested in other areas of science and education.

How can we change the education system? Not a total science question, I know. Here's why I ask it though. I was an educator, and still know many. We get out of school expecting to change the broken system we just came from. A system that values measurable results through universal testing and conformity. Many of us leave the education system when it becomes clear we can't change anything in it. We're handed curriculum we must follow, we are encouraged to teach to a test, and teach in a way that scientifically we know doesn't work. And we continue in our ways because of the "it was good enough for me." mentality and find kids turning to places like YouTube to get answers to questions that aren't/can't be addressed at school. The US still ranks extremely low compared to other countries educational systems. So how can we as students, teachers, parents, and members of the community actually change our system when Washington doesn't, or doesn't want to, hear?

You'll have to reframe it better than I can but here's the idea:

How come the scientific community has so little participation in the political decision making process? What can the population and the president do to improve upon this?

Most politicians are not formally trained or even knowledgeable in science and technology, and this reflects terribly on their decisions. Science is not represented in politics at all, it seems.

We have in the US policies that don't take into account the necessity of clean renewable energy, we have constant attempts at limiting scientific education, technological freedom and security as if these were good things (it's for "our safety"), or even possible in principle (as in the case of cryptography, with the recent push for broken cryptography). We also have diminishing investment and support for science.

In general, we have a bunch of lawyers and businessmen making decisions on science and technology issues. This is unacceptable. How do we change this?

I don't think it's feasible to simply elect scientists as politicians, because scientists should be doing science. The point of politicians is to represent society, but this falls short when it requires technical and specialized knowledge.

So there needs to be a system where scientists get a more prominent influence in policy-making, instead of hoping politicians to be scientifically literate enough. What could work?
